Mass. R. Civ. P. 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under Mass. R. Civ. P. 2 and related venue statutes because the cause of action arose in Lowell and the defendant’s property is located in Lowell.

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: A landlord’s wrongful act or omission that substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including failure to remediate conditions that affect habitability or materially impair health and safety, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standar.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standar.proposition: The Massachusetts Sanitary Code and related public-health laws set minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and require landlords to maintain premises free from conditions hazardous to health, such as mold and inadequate ventilation.

M.G.L. c. 111 (public health).proposition: The Massachusetts Sanitary Code and related public-health laws set minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and require landlords to maintain premises free from conditions hazardous to health, such as mold and inadequate ventilation.

M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186 and related landlord-tenant law, landlords have duties to keep premises in habitable condition and to refrain from conduct that unjustifiably interferes with tenants’ rights to possession and use.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: The following statutes, regulations, and decisions illustrate applicable legal authorities concerning landlords’ duties, habitability, and the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly adopts and defines an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, discusses landlords’ obligations to maintain safe and habitable premises, and details tenant remedies including rent withholding and damages. It also addresses the historical constructive eviction doctrine and replaces it with a contract-based habitability framework, which is closely related to the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it is directly relevant as an authority on landlords’ duties, habitability, and related tenant protections.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation… Because of our holding in this case, the doctrine of constructive eviction, wherein the tenant must abandon in order to escape liability for rent, is no longer viable. When… the tenant seeks… to receive compensatory damages in the amount of rent already paid, abandonment is similarly unnecessary.”
